column1: # Advantages and Disadvantages of Relational Databases (RDBMS) vs NoSQL Databases
Relational databases store data in structured tables with predefined schemas and relationships enforced by primary and foreign keys.

column5: ideal for financial and enterprise systems.

column1: - Predefined schemas maintain consistency and logical organization for data accuracy.
- Extensive community and vendor support with decades of refinement.
- Best suited for applications requiring strong entity relationships such as products

column2: potentially becoming costly for large systems.

column1: - Schema changes can require migrations and potential downtime.
- Large datasets or many joins may reduce performance.

column5: and unstructured data by avoiding rigid schemas.

column2: allowing easy adaptations as applications evolve.

column1: - Supports distributed systems that scale across multiple servers.
- Optimized for fast reads/writes in large-scale or real-time applications.
- Built-in replication and sharding ensure uptime and resilience.
- Each system has unique query languages and interfaces.
- Multi-document transactions are less reliable than in RDBMS.
- Rapidly evolving tools with less standardization than traditional RDBMS environments.
| Query Language       | SQL (standardized)                       | Proprietary or API-based                       |
| Performance          | Great for structured data                | Optimized for large-scale/unstructured data    |
| Use Case Focus       | Data integrity and complex relationships | High speed
- Data is highly structured with clear relationships.
- Complex joins and consistency are essential.
- Working with unstructured data like user-generated content.
| Data Consistency  | Strong guarantees (ACID)        | Eventual consistency (BASE)       |
- Relational databases excel at data integrity and complex relationships.
